caption.p: Potentially toxic essential oils and their toxic constituents discussed in this review.

tr.td: Neocallitropsis pancheri (Carriere) de Laub. (synonym: Callitropsis araucarioides Compton, and Neocallitropsis araucarioides (Compton) Florin)
β-eudesmol (25.9%), γ-eudesmol (19.0%), α-eudesmol (13.3%), guaiol (6.0%), elemol (5.0%), and β-bisabolenol (4.9%)
Eucalyptus staigeriana F. v. Muell. ex F. M. Bailey
d-limonene+ β-phellandrene (30.5%), geranial (9.9%), neral (7.7%), α-phellandrene (7.1%), and terpinolene (6.6%)
Foeniculum vulgare Mill. subsp. capillaceum Gilib.
( E)-anethole (52.5–84.3%), fenchone (4.0–24.0%), α-pinene (tr-10.4%), d-limonene (0.5–9.4%), and estragole (2.8–6.5%).
Black seed (black cumin or black caraway)
thymoquinone (26.8–54.8%), p-cymene (14.7–38.0%), longifolene (1.2–10.2%), and α-thujene (1.3–10.1%) as the main constituents.
Callitris intratropica R.T. Baker and H.B. Sm.
β-eudesmol (14.4%), dihydrocolumellarin (14.0%), guaiol (13.7%), γ-eudesmol (9.1%), α-eudesmol (7.6%), guaiazulene (6.2%), chamazulene (5.6%)
isomenthone (4.6–29.1%), limonene (11.6–28.2%), disophenol (12.0–26.3%), menthone (2.5–25.0%), c-diosphenol (10.3–23.3%), and 8-mercapto- p-menthan-3-one( cis-trans) (0.7–6.6%)
(1 R)-(+)-β-pulegone (31.6–73.2%), isomenthone (3.6–27.6%), limonene (2.1–17.2%), ( E)-8-acetylthio- p-menthan-3-one (0.4–10.4%), and menthone (1.3–7.0%)
Daucus carota L. subsp. sativus Hoffm.
Cinnamomum cassia (L.) J. Presl (synonym: Cinnamomum aromaticum Nees)

( E)-cinnamaldehyde (73.2–89.4%), ( Z)-cinnamaldehyde (0.8–12.3%), and ( E)-cinnamyl acetate (0.1–5.4%) while in the leaf oil ( E)-cinnamaldehyde (54.6–90.1%), ( E)-cinnamyl acetate (1.4–12.5%), ( Z)-cinnamaldehyde (0.4–10.5%), and benzaldehyde (1.1–6.3%)

Leaf EO: 1,8-cineole (15.6–35.2%), sabinene (6.9–17.1%), α-pinene (1.0–13.9%), α-terpineol (1.4–9.2%), γ-elemene (0–9.1%), β-selinene (0–9.0%), β-caryophyllene (2.3–8.9%), ( Z)-β-farnesene (0–8.6%), citronellyl acetate (0.3–7.8%), and citronellic acid (0–6.6%). Seed EO: sabinene (7.1–44.1%), 1,8-cineole (8.4–23.3%), α-pinene (1.2–23.1%), γ-elemene (0–17.0%), ( E)-β-farnesene (0–10.3%), β-caryophyllene (0.8–9.3%), α-terpineol (0.2–9.3%), limonene (0.5–7.4%), ( Z)-β-farnesene (0–6.9%), citronellyl acetate (0.2–6.0%), β-selinene (0–6.0%), and β-myrcene (0–5.6%).
Cinnamomum verum J. Presl. (Synonym: Cinnamomum zeylanicum Blume)

( E)-cinnamaldehyde (63.1–75.7%), eugenol (2.0–13.3%), ( E)-cinnamyl acetate (0.3–10.6%), linalool (0.2–7.0%), and β-caryophyllene (1.3–5.8%)

camphor (7.3–50.2%), α-thujone (13.1–48.5%), borneol (1.5–23.9%), 1,8-cineole (1.8–21.7%), β-thujone (3.9–19.1%), β-caryophyllene (0.2–9.7%), camphene (0–8.6%), α-pinene (0–8.0%) and bornyl acetate (0.3–5.7%)

Achillea nobilis L. (synonym: A. ligustica Vis. ex Nym.)
Aerial parts of the flowering plant
camphor (13.7%) artemisia alcohol (9.2%), germacrene D (8.8%), artemisia ketone (8.7%) and viridiflorol (5.7%)
dill apiole (20.7–52.5%), d-limonene (5.9–45.0%), (+)-carvone (17.4–23.1%), ( E)-dihydrocarvone (4.2–16.6%), α-phellandrene (tr–6.5%), and ( Z)-dihydrocarvone (0.8–5.2%)
α-thujone (22.5%), ( E)-chrysanthenyl acetate (19.2%), 1,8-cineole (19.1%), camphor (11.0%), and β-thujone (8.9%)
Citrus × limon L. (synonym: Citrus limonum Risso)

geranial (10.9–39.0%), limonene (8.1–30.7%), neral (6.5–25.3%), geraniol (0.5–15.0%), β-pinene (3.5–13.6%), neryl acetate (3.7–7.4%), nerol (1.3–7.4%), α-terpinyl acetate (tr–7.3%), and linalyl acetate (tr–6.5%)

Cymbopogon flexuosus Nees ex Steud. (synonym.: Andropogon flexuosus Nees ex Steud.) (East Indian) and Cymbopogon citratus DC (synonym: Andropogon citratus DC) (West Indian)

list-item.p: East Indian lemongrass: geranial (45.1–54.5%) and neral (30.1–36.1%).
West Indian lemongrass: geranial (36.7–55.9%), neral (25.0–35.2%), β-myrcene (5.6–19.2%), geraniol (0–6.7%), and limonene oxide (0–6.4%)

Mugwort or Indian wormwood oil (camphor/thujone CT)
